intro: Batidophaca obcordata, commonly known as the obcordate batidophaca, is a flowering plant species native to specific regions in South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and broad, heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, five-petaled flowers that are typically pink or purple in color, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release small, hairy seeds, aiding in its dispersal. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
